content:
Please execute the following task in my repository mcpmark-eval-zl/claude-code:

I need you to implement a comprehensive label documentation and organization workflow for the repository.

**Step 1: Create Label Documentation Issue**
Create a new issue with:
- Title containing: "Document label organization for better visual organization" and "label guide"
- Body must include:
  - A "## Problem" heading describing the need for better label documentation
  - A "## Proposed Solution" heading about creating a comprehensive label guide for different label categories
  - A "## Benefits" heading listing improved visual organization and easier issue triage
  - Keywords: "label documentation", "visual organization", "label guide", "organization"
- Labels: Initially add "enhancement" and "documentation" labels to the issue

**Step 2: Create Feature Branch**
Create a new branch called 'feat/label-color-guide' from main.

**Step 3: Create Label Documentation**
On the feature branch, create the file `docs/LABEL_COLORS.md` with:
- A "# Label Organization Guide" title
- A "## Label Categories" section with a table that MUST follow this exact format:
```markdown
| Label Name | Category | Description |
|------------|----------|-------------|
```
The table must include ALL existing labels in the repository. For each label:
- Group labels by category (e.g., issue-type, platform, area, status, performance)
- Include a description for each label

- A "## Usage Guidelines" section explaining when to use each label category

**Step 4: Apply ALL Labels to the Documentation Issue**
Update the issue you created in Step 1 by adding ALL existing labels from the repository. This serves as a visual demonstration of the label organization. The issue should have every single label that exists in the repository applied to it.

**Step 5: Create Pull Request**
Create a pull request from 'feat/label-color-guide' to 'main' with:
- Title containing: "Add label organization guide" and "visual organization"  
- Body must include:
  - A "## Summary" heading explaining the label organization documentation
  - A "## Changes" heading with a bullet list of what was added
  - "Fixes #[ISSUE_NUMBER]" pattern linking to your created issue
  - A "## Verification" section stating that all labels have been documented
  - Keywords: "label documentation", "organization guide", "visual improvement", "documentation"
- Labels: Add a reasonable subset of labels to the PR (at least 5-10 labels from different categories)

**Step 6: Document Changes in Issue**
Add a comment to the original issue with:
- Confirmation that the label documentation has been created
- Total count of labels documented
- Reference to the PR using "PR #[NUMBER]" pattern
- Keywords: "documentation created", "label guide complete", "organization complete"

Note: Based on your understanding, solve the task all at once by yourself, don't ask for my opinions on anything.

comprehensive overview of all labels used in this repository, their categories, and usage guidelines for consistent project organization.\\n\\n## Label Categories\\n\\n| Label Name | Category | Description |\\n|------------|----------|-------------|\\n| area:api | Area | Issues related to API functionality and interfaces |\\n| area:auth | Area | Issues related to authentication and authorization |\\n| area:core | Area | Issues related to core system functionality |\\n| area:ide | Area | Issues related to IDE integration and features |\\n| area:mcp | Area | Issues related to MCP (Model Context Protocol) implementation |\\n| area:model | Area | Issues related to AI model integration and behavior |\\n| area:packaging | Area | Issues related to software packaging and distribution |\\n| area:security | Area | Issues related to security concerns and vulnerabilities |\\n| area:tools | Area | Issues related to development tools and utilities |\\n| area:tui | Area | Issues related to text-based user interface |\\n| bug | Issue Type | Something isn't working as expected |\\n| enhancement | Issue Type | New feature requests or improvements to existing functionality |\\n| documentation | Issue Type | Improvements or additions to project documentation |\\n| question | Issue Type | Requests for information or clarification |\\n| platform:linux | Platform | Issues specific to Linux operating system |\\n| platform:macos | Platform | Issues specific to macOS operating system |\\n| platform:windows | Platform | Issues specific to Windows operating system |\\n| perf:memory | Performance | Issues related to memory usage and optimization |\\n| memory | Performance | General memory-related issues |\\n| good first issue | Status | Issues suitable for newcomers to the project |\\n| help wanted | Status | Issues where community assistance is particularly welcome |\\n| has repro | Status | Issues that have a reproducible test case or example |\\n| external | Status | Issues related to external dependencies or systems |\\n| duplicate | Resolution | Issues that duplicate existing reports |\\n| invalid | Resolution | Issues that don't seem to be valid problems |\\n| wontfix | Resolution | Issues that will not be addressed |\\n\\n## Usage Guidelines\\n\\n### Area Labels\\n- **Purpose**: Categorize issues by the part of the system they affect\\n- **Usage**: Apply one or more area labels to help route issues to appropriate team members\\n- **Color**: Light gray (#ededed) for visual consistency\\n\\n### Issue Type Labels\\n- **Purpose**: Classify the nature of the issue or request\\n- **Usage**: Every issue should have exactly one issue type label\\n- **Colors**: \\n  - `bug`: Red (#d73a4a) for urgent attention\\n  - `enhancement`: Blue (#a2eeef) for feature requests\\n  - `documentation`: Dark blue (#0075ca) for doc improvements\\n  - `question`: Purple (#d876e3) for information requests\\n\\n### Platform Labels\\n- **Purpose**: Indicate operating system specific issues\\n- **Usage**: Apply when the issue is specific to a particular platform\\n- **Color**: Light gray (#ededed) for neutrality\\n\\n### Performance Labels\\n- **Purpose**: Highlight performance-related concerns\\n- **Usage**: Use for issues affecting system performance, particularly memory usage\\n- **Color**: Light gray (#ededed)\\n\\n### Status Labels\\n- **Purpose**: Indicate the current state or priority of an issue\\n- **Usage**: Apply to help with issue triage and community engagement\\n- **Colors**:\\n  - `good first issue`: Purple (#7057ff) to attract newcomers\\n  - `help wanted`: Green (#008672) to encourage community participation\\n  - `has repro`: Light gray (#ededed) for technical status\\n  - `external`: Light gray (#ededed) for dependency issues\\n\\n### Resolution Labels\\n- **Purpose**: Indicate the final disposition of closed issues\\n- **Usage**: Apply when closing issues to provide context for the resolution\\n- **Colors**:\\n  - `duplicate`: Light gray (#cfd3d7)\\n  - `invalid`: Yellow (#e4e669) for attention\\n  - `wontfix`: White (#ffffff) for clear distinction\\n\\n## Best Practices\\n\\n1. **Issue Creation**: Always apply at least one issue type and relevant area labels\\n2. **Platform Specific**: Add platform labels only when the issue is platform-specific\\n3. **Performance Issues**: Use both general and specific performance labels when applicable\\n4. **Community Engagement**: Use status labels to guide community contributions\\n5. **Resolution Documentation**: Always apply appropriate resolution labels when closing issues\\n\\n## Label Maintenance\\n\\nThis document should be updated whenever:\\n- New labels are added to the repository\\n- Existing labels are modified or removed\\n- Label usage guidelines change\\n- Label color schemes are updated\\n\\nFor questions about label usage, please refer to this guide or ask in the project discussions.\", \"branch\": \"feat/label-color-guide\"}", "include_output_fields": ["commit.sha", "commit.message"]}
